2 Registered in CVs CMIP6Plus None None registered None PCMDI-AMIP-OI2p1-1-0 zelinka1@llnl.gov; durack1@llnl.gov None None None https://pcmdi.llnl.gov/mips/amip None PCMDI CC BY 4.0 None 1.0 Prototype None
3 Registered in CVs CMIP6Plus None None registered None UReading-CCMI-1-1 Michaela Hegglin (m.i.hegglin@fz-juelich.de); Douglas Kinnison (dkin@ucar.edu); David Plummer (david.plummer@ec.gc.ca) None None None https://input4mips-cvs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dataset-overviews/ozone None UReading CC BY 4.0 None 1.1 None None
4 Published CMIP6Plus BC True published Differences with CMIP6-1-2: The dataset contains data until December 2022 based on GFED4s Global Fire Emissions. Furthermore CO2 has been added as separate species. This dataset has been developed for the testing phase of CMIP7. DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0 extends the data to 2023. Modellers are advised to use DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0. Tables for validation of the data of various species, geographical areas and sectors can be found on https://www.geo.vu.nl/~gwerf/GFED/GFED4/tables/ for the 1997 onwards period. DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-1-0 Margreet.vanMarle@Deltares.nl, Guido.vanderWerf@wur.nl None emissions mon http://www.globalfiredata.org gn DRES CC BY 4.0 atmos 1.0 CMIP 175001-202212
5 Published CMIP6Plus BC_em_AIR_anthro True published None CEDS-CMIP-2024-10-21 Rachel Hoesly (rachel.hoesly@pnnl.gov); Steve Smith (ssmith@pnnl.gov) 10.5281/zenodo.13952845 emissions mon https://www.pnnl.gov/projects/ceds gn PNNL-JGCRI None atmos missing CMIP 175001-202212
6 Published CMIP6Plus BC_em_SOLID_BIOFUEL_anthro True published A number of updates have been made in CEDS-CMIP-2025-03-18*. These are significantly different from this dataset, hence it has been retracted. CEDS-CMIP-2024-11-25-supplemental Rachel Hoesly (rachel.hoesly@pnnl.gov); Steve Smith (ssmith@pnnl.gov) 10.5281/zenodo.14145000 emissions mon https://www.pnnl.gov/projects/ceds gn PNNL-JGCRI CC BY 4.0 atmos 2024-11-25 CMIP 175001-202212
7 Published CMIP6Plus BC_em_anthro True published A number of updates have been made in CEDS-CMIP-2025-03-18*. These are significantly different from this dataset, hence it has been retracted. CEDS-CMIP-2024-11-25 Rachel Hoesly (rachel.hoesly@pnnl.gov); Steve Smith (ssmith@pnnl.gov) 10.5281/zenodo.14145000 emissions mon https://www.pnnl.gov/projects/ceds gn PNNL-JGCRI CC BY 4.0 atmos 2024-11-25 CMIP 175001-202212
8 Published CMIP6Plus BCpercentageAGRI True published Differences with CMIP6-1-2: The dataset contains data until December 2022 based on GFED4s Global Fire Emissions. Furthermore CO2 has been added as separate species. This dataset has been developed for the testing phase of CMIP7. DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0 extends the data to 2023. Modellers are advised to use DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0. Tables for validation of the data of various species, geographical areas and sectors can be found on https://www.geo.vu.nl/~gwerf/GFED/GFED4/tables/ for the 1997 onwards period. DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-1-0 Margreet.vanMarle@Deltares.nl, Guido.vanderWerf@wur.nl None emissions mon http://www.globalfiredata.org gn DRES CC BY 4.0 atmos 1.0 CMIP 175001-202212

36 Published CMIP6Plus C2H4percentageAGRI True published Differences with CMIP6-1-2: The dataset contains data until December 2022 based on GFED4s Global Fire Emissions. Furthermore CO2 has been added as separate species. This dataset has been developed for the testing phase of CMIP7. DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0 extends the data to 2023. Modellers are advised to use DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0. Tables for validation of the data of various species, geographical areas and sectors can be found on https://www.geo.vu.nl/~gwerf/GFED/GFED4/tables/ for the 1997 onwards period. DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-1-0 Margreet.vanMarle@Deltares.nl, Guido.vanderWerf@wur.nl None emissions mon http://www.globalfiredata.org gn DRES CC BY 4.0 atmos 1.0 CMIP 175001-202212

Modellers are advised to use DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0. DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-1-0 Margreet.vanMarle@Deltares.nl, Guido.vanderWerf@wur.nl None emissions mon http://www.globalfiredata.org gn DRES CC BY 4.0 atmos 1.0 CMIP 175001-202212
70 Published CMIP6Plus C3H6OpercentageTEMF True published Differences with CMIP6-1-2: The dataset contains data until December 2022 based on GFED4s Global Fire Emissions. Furthermore CO2 has been added as separate species. This dataset has been developed for the testing phase of CMIP7. DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0 extends the data to 2023. Modellers are advised to use DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0. Tables for validation of the data of various species, geographical areas and sectors can be found on https://www.geo.vu.nl/~gwerf/GFED/GFED4/tables/ for the 1997 onwards period. Modellers are advised to use DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0. DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-1-0 Margreet.vanMarle@Deltares.nl, Guido.vanderWerf@wur.nl None emissions mon http://www.globalfiredata.org gn DRES CC BY 4.0 atmos 1.0 CMIP 175001-202212
103 Published CMIP6Plus C7H8percentageSAVA True published Differences with CMIP6-1-2: The dataset contains data until December 2022 based on GFED4s Global Fire Emissions. Furthermore CO2 has been added as separate species. This dataset has been developed for the testing phase of CMIP7. DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0 extends the data to 2023. Modellers are advised to use DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0. Tables for validation of the data of various species, geographical areas and sectors can be found on https://www.geo.vu.nl/~gwerf/GFED/GFED4/tables/ for the 1997 onwards period. 136 Published CMIP6Plus CH3OHpercentageDEFO True published Differences with CMIP6-1-2: The dataset contains data until December 2022 based on GFED4s Global Fire Emissions. Furthermore CO2 has been added as separate species. This dataset has been developed for the testing phase of CMIP7. DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0 extends the data to 2023. Modellers are advised to use DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0. Tables for validation of the data of various species, geographical areas and sectors can be found on https://www.geo.vu.nl/~gwerf/GFED/GFED4/tables/ for the 1997 onwards period. Modellers are advised to use DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0. DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-1-0 Margreet.vanMarle@Deltares.nl, Guido.vanderWerf@wur.nl None emissions mon http://www.globalfiredata.org gn DRES CC BY 4.0 atmos 1.0 CMIP 175001-202212
173 Published CMIP6Plus H2percentageDEFO True published Differences with CMIP6-1-2: The dataset contains data until December 2022 based on GFED4s Global Fire Emissions. Furthermore CO2 has been added as separate species. This dataset has been developed for the testing phase of CMIP7. DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0 extends the data to 2023. Modellers are advised to use DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0. Tables for validation of the data of various species, geographical areas and sectors can be found on https://www.geo.vu.nl/~gwerf/GFED/GFED4/tables/ for the 1997 onwards period. 206 Published CMIP6Plus HigherAlkenespercentageDEFO True published Differences with CMIP6-1-2: The dataset contains data until December 2022 based on GFED4s Global Fire Emissions. Furthermore CO2 has been added as separate species. This dataset has been developed for the testing phase of CMIP7. DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0 extends the data to 2023. Modellers are advised to use DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0. Tables for validation of the data of various species, geographical areas and sectors can be found on https://www.geo.vu.nl/~gwerf/GFED/GFED4/tables/ for the 1997 onwards period. 245 Published CMIP6Plus NMVOCbulkpercentageDEFO True published Differences with CMIP6-1-2: The dataset contains data until December 2022 based on GFED4s Global Fire Emissions. Furthermore CO2 has been added as separate species. This dataset has been developed for the testing phase of CMIP7. DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0 extends the data to 2023. Modellers are advised to use DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0. Tables for validation of the data of various species, geographical areas and sectors can be found on https://www.geo.vu.nl/~gwerf/GFED/GFED4/tables/ for the 1997 onwards period. Modellers are advised to use DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0. Tables for validation of the data of various species, geographical areas and sectors can be found on https://www.geo.vu.nl/~gwerf/GFED/GFED4/tables/ for the 1997 onwards period. DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-1-0 Margreet.vanMarle@Deltares.nl, Guido.vanderWerf@wur.nl None emissions mon http://www.globalfiredata.org gn DRES CC BY 4.0 atmos 1.0 CMIP 175001-202212
282 Published CMIP6Plus SO2percentageDEFO True published Differences with CMIP6-1-2: The dataset contains data until December 2022 based on GFED4s Global Fire Emissions. Furthermore CO2 has been added as separate species. This dataset has been developed for the testing phase of CMIP7. DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0 extends the data to 2023. Modellers are advised to use DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0. Tables for validation of the data of various species, geographical areas and sectors can be found on https://www.geo.vu.nl/~gwerf/GFED/GFED4/tables/ for the 1997 onwards period. 321 Published CMIP6Plus asy False published v1.3.1 does minor plus updates and adds the aerosol number density requested by some modelling groups. Hence v1.3.0 is deprecated. UOEXETER-CMIP-1-3-0 t.aubry@exeter.ac.uk None aerosolProperties mon https://input4mips-controlled-vocabularies-cvs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dataset-overviews/stratospheric-volcanic-so2-emissions-aod/ gnz uoexeter CC BY 4.0 atmos 1.3.0 CMIP 175001-202312
322 Published CMIP6Plus asy True published v2.0.0 includes the following key updates: i) new H2SO4 number density variable replacing aerosol number density; ii) correction to the 1920-1978 ice-core dataset, improving consistency with pyrheliometer measurements and CMIP6. As a result of this change, the mean historical SAOD has decreased a bit, but it is still higher than CMIP6. Hence v1.3.1 is deprecated. UOEXETER-CMIP-1-3-1 t.aubry@exeter.ac.uk None aerosolProperties mon https://input4mips-controlled-vocabularies-cvs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dataset-overviews/stratospheric-volcanic-so2-emissions-aod/ gnz uoexeter CC BY 4.0 atmos 1.3.1 CMIP 175001-202312

325 Published CMIP6Plus asy True published v2.0.0 includes the following key updates: i) new H2SO4 number density variable replacing aerosol number density; ii) correction to the 1920-1978 ice-core dataset, improving consistency with pyrheliometer measurements and CMIP6. As a result of this change, the mean historical SAOD has decreased a bit, but it is still higher than CMIP6. Hence v1.3.1 is deprecated. UOEXETER-CMIP-1-3-1 t.aubry@exeter.ac.uk None aerosolProperties monC https://input4mips-controlled-vocabularies-cvs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dataset-overviews/stratospheric-volcanic-so2-emissions-aod/ gnz uoexeter CC BY 4.0 atmos 1.3.1 CMIP 185001-202112
326 Published CMIP6Plus ccl4 False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 000101-202212
327 Published CMIP6Plus ccl4 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212
328 Published CMIP6Plus ccl4 False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gnz CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 000101-202212

A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 335 Published CMIP6Plus ccl4 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212
348 Published CMIP6Plus cfc11 False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gnz CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 000101-202212

CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212
368 Published CMIP6Plus cfc114 False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gnz CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 000101-202212

A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. 387 Published CMIP6Plus cfc11eq True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212
388 Published CMIP6Plus cfc11eq False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gnz CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 000101-202212
389 Published CMIP6Plus cfc11eq True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gnz CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212

A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. 407 Published CMIP6Plus cfc12eq True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212
408 Published CMIP6Plus cfc12eq False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gnz CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 000101-202212
409 Published CMIP6Plus cfc12eq True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gnz CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212

A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. 415 Published CMIP6Plus cfc12eq True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 417 Published CMIP6Plus ch2cl2 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212
428 Published CMIP6Plus ch3br False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gnz CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 000101-202212
429 Published CMIP6Plus ch3br True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gnz CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212

A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. 437 Published CMIP6Plus ch3cl True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 448 Published CMIP6Plus ch4 False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gnz CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 000101-202212
449 Published CMIP6Plus ch4 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gnz CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212

As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gr1z CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 000101-202212
451 Published CMIP6Plus ch4 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 453 Published CMIP6Plus ch4 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 455 Published CMIP6Plus ch4 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 000101-202212
457 Published CMIP6Plus chcl3 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). 461 Published CMIP6Plus chcl3 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gnz CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 000101-202212
469 Published CMIP6Plus co2 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gnz CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212

As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). 473 Published CMIP6Plus co2 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations yr http://www.tbd.invalid gr1z CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 0001-2022
476 Published CMIP6Plus datasource True published Differences with CMIP6-1-2: The dataset contains data until December 2022 based on GFED4s Global Fire Emissions. Furthermore CO2 has been added as separate species. This dataset has been developed for the testing phase of CMIP7. DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0 extends the data to 2023. Modellers are advised to use DRES-CMIP-BB4CMIP7-2-0. Tables for validation of the data of various species, geographical areas and sectors can be found on https://www.geo.vu.nl/~gwerf/GFED/GFED4/tables/ for the 1997 onwards period. UOEXETER-CMIP-1-3-0 t.aubry@exeter.ac.uk None aerosolProperties mon https://input4mips-controlled-vocabularies-cvs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dataset-overviews/stratospheric-volcanic-so2-emissions-aod/ gnz uoexeter CC BY 4.0 atmos 1.3.0 CMIP 175001-202312
496 Published CMIP6Plus ext True published v2.0.0 includes the following key updates: i) new H2SO4 number density variable replacing aerosol number density; ii) correction to the 1920-1978 ice-core dataset, improving consistency with pyrheliometer measurements and CMIP6. As a result of this change, the mean historical SAOD has decreased a bit, but it is still higher than CMIP6. Hence v1.3.1 is deprecated. UOEXETER-CMIP-1-3-1 t.aubry@exeter.ac.uk None aerosolProperties mon https://input4mips-controlled-vocabularies-cvs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dataset-overviews/stratospheric-volcanic-so2-emissions-aod/ gnz uoexeter CC BY 4.0 atmos 1.3.1 CMIP 175001-202312

507 Published CMIP6Plus halon1211 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gr1z CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212
508 Published CMIP6Plus halon1211 False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations yr http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 0001-2022
509 Published CMIP6Plus halon1211 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 511 Published CMIP6Plus halon1211 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 513 Published CMIP6Plus halon1301 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gnz CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 000101-202212
515 Published CMIP6Plus halon1301 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 517 Published CMIP6Plus halon1301 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 519 Published CMIP6Plus halon1301 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 523 Published CMIP6Plus halon2402 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. 527 Published CMIP6Plus halon2402 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gr1z CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212
528 Published CMIP6Plus halon2402 False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. 535 Published CMIP6Plus hcc140a True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gr1z CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212
548 Published CMIP6Plus hcfc141b False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks.
