The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. 567 Published CMIP6Plus hcfc22 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gr1z CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212
568 Published CMIP6Plus hcfc22 False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations yr http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 0001-2022
569 Published CMIP6Plus hcfc22 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations yr http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 0001-2022

The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. 573 Published CMIP6Plus hfc125 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 575 Published CMIP6Plus hfc125 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. 587 Published CMIP6Plus hfc134a True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gr1z CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212
588 Published CMIP6Plus hfc134a False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations yr http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 0001-2022
589 Published CMIP6Plus hfc134a True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations yr http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 0001-2022

A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. 593 Published CMIP6Plus hfc134aeq True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). 607 Published CMIP6Plus hfc143a True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gr1z CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212
608 Published CMIP6Plus hfc143a False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations yr http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 0001-2022
609 Published CMIP6Plus hfc143a True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations yr http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 0001-2022

A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. 613 Published CMIP6Plus hfc152a True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gnz CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 000101-202212
615 Published CMIP6Plus hfc152a True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 617 Published CMIP6Plus hfc152a True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gr1z CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212
628 Published CMIP6Plus hfc227ea False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations yr http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 0001-2022
629 Published CMIP6Plus hfc227ea True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations yr http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 0001-2022

A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. 635 Published CMIP6Plus hfc23 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 637 Published CMIP6Plus hfc23 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gr1z CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212
648 Published CMIP6Plus hfc236fa False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations yr http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 0001-2022
649 Published CMIP6Plus hfc236fa True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations yr http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 0001-2022

As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). 651 Published CMIP6Plus hfc236fa True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 653 Published CMIP6Plus hfc245fa True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 655 Published CMIP6Plus hfc245fa True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 657 Published CMIP6Plus hfc245fa True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 661 Published CMIP6Plus hfc245fa True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 663 Published CMIP6Plus hfc32 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 668 Published CMIP6Plus hfc32 False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations yr http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 0001-2022
669 Published CMIP6Plus hfc32 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations yr http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 0001-2022

As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). 671 Published CMIP6Plus hfc32 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 673 Published CMIP6Plus hfc365mfc True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 675 Published CMIP6Plus hfc365mfc True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 677 Published CMIP6Plus hfc365mfc True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 681 Published CMIP6Plus hfc365mfc True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations yr http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 0001-2022
689 Published CMIP6Plus hfc4310mee True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations yr http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 0001-2022

It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. 694 Published CMIP6Plus multiple-management True published v3.0 contains a number of spurious spikes post-1950. These have been addressed in v3.1. As a result, v3.0 has been retracted. 698 Published CMIP6Plus n2o False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 000101-202212
699 Published CMIP6Plus n2o True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212

A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. 708 Published CMIP6Plus nd True published v2.0.0 includes the following key updates: i) new H2SO4 number density variable replacing aerosol number density; ii) correction to the 1920-1978 ice-core dataset, improving consistency with pyrheliometer measurements and CMIP6. As a result of this change, the mean historical SAOD has decreased a bit, but it is still higher than CMIP6. Hence v1.3.1 is deprecated. UOEXETER-CMIP-1-3-1 t.aubry@exeter.ac.uk None aerosolProperties mon https://input4mips-controlled-vocabularies-cvs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dataset-overviews/stratospheric-volcanic-so2-emissions-aod/ gnz uoexeter CC BY 4.0 atmos 1.3.1 CMIP 175001-202312

As a result of this change, the mean historical SAOD has decreased a bit, but it is still higher than CMIP6. Hence v1.3.1 is deprecated. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gnz CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212
714 Published CMIP6Plus nf3 False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gr1z CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 000101-202212
715 Published CMIP6Plus nf3 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gr1z CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212

As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 719 Published CMIP6Plus nf3 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 721 Published CMIP6Plus pfc116 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 723 Published CMIP6Plus pfc116 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gnz CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212
734 Published CMIP6Plus pfc218 False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gr1z CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 000101-202212
735 Published CMIP6Plus pfc218 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gr1z CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212

A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. 741 Published CMIP6Plus pfc3110 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 743 Published CMIP6Plus pfc3110 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations).
