CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gnz CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212
754 Published CMIP6Plus pfc318 False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gr1z CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 000101-202212
755 Published CMIP6Plus pfc318 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gr1z CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212

As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). 757 Published CMIP6Plus pfc318 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 759 Published CMIP6Plus pfc318 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 761 Published CMIP6Plus pfc4112 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gnz CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 000101-202212
763 Published CMIP6Plus pfc4112 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gnz CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212

A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. 767 Published CMIP6Plus pfc4112 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. 774 Published CMIP6Plus pfc5114 False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gr1z CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 000101-202212
775 Published CMIP6Plus pfc5114 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gr1z CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212

As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations yr http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 0001-2022
777 Published CMIP6Plus pfc5114 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations yr http://www.tbd.invalid gr1z CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 0001-2022
779 Published CMIP6Plus pfc5114 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 000101-202212
781 Published CMIP6Plus pfc6116 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212

As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gnz CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 000101-202212
783 Published CMIP6Plus pfc6116 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gnz CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212

For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). 785 Published CMIP6Plus pfc6116 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 787 Published CMIP6Plus pfc6116 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 789 Published CMIP6Plus pfc6116 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 791 Published CMIP6Plus pfc7118 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 793 Published CMIP6Plus pfc7118 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). 794 Published CMIP6Plus pfc7118 False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gr1z CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 000101-202212
795 Published CMIP6Plus pfc7118 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gr1z CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212

As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). 805 Published CMIP6Plus reff False published v1.3.1 does minor plus updates and adds the aerosol number density requested by some modelling groups. Hence v1.3.0 is deprecated. UOEXETER-CMIP-1-3-0 t.aubry@exeter.ac.uk None aerosolProperties mon https://input4mips-controlled-vocabularies-cvs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dataset-overviews/stratospheric-volcanic-so2-emissions-aod/ gnz uoexeter CC BY 4.0 atmos 1.3.0 CMIP 175001-202312
806 Published CMIP6Plus reff True published v2.0.0 includes the following key updates: i) new H2SO4 number density variable replacing aerosol number density; ii) correction to the 1920-1978 ice-core dataset, improving consistency with pyrheliometer measurements and CMIP6. As a result of this change, the mean historical SAOD has decreased a bit, but it is still higher than CMIP6. Hence v1.3.1 is deprecated. CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 000101-202212
820 Published CMIP6Plus sf6 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations yr http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 0001-2022
827 Published CMIP6Plus sf6 False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations yr http://www.tbd.invalid gr1z CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 0001-2022
828 Published CMIP6Plus sf6 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations yr http://www.tbd.invalid gr1z CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 0001-2022

835 Published CMIP6Plus so2f2 False published A number of bugs were identified in v0.3.0, see [https://github.com/PCMDI/input4MIPs_CVs/discussions/144](). As far as we are aware, v0.4.0 fixes all major bugs identified in v0.3.0. For the full list of updates since v0.3.0 (and before), see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md](). For further analysis of the changes between versions, see [https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations](). CR-CMIP-0-3-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com None GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.3.0 CMIP 000101-202212
836 Published CMIP6Plus so2f2 True published CR-CMIP-1-0-0 switches to much more conventional naming for gases. The affected gases are: c2f6 (previously pfc116), c3f8 (pfc218), c4f10 (pfc3110), c5f12 (pfc4112), c6f14 (pfc5114), c7f16 (pfc6116), c8f18 (pfc7118), cc4f8 (pfc318) and ch3ccl3 (hcc140a). A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. It also uses the Scripps CO2 record to handle the period from 1959 to the start of the flask and in-situ samples from other networks. The CR-CMIP-1-0-0 dataset also provides much better information about the original data sources. As a result, CR-CMIP-0-4-0 is deprecated. For the full CHANGELOG, see [here](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP-GHG-Concentration-Generation/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md). For basic analysis of the changes between versions, see [this repo](https://github.com/climate-resource/CMIP6-vs-CMIP7-GHG-Concentrations). CR-CMIP-0-4-0 zebedee.nicholls@climate-resource.com;malte.meinshausen@climate-resource.com 10.5281/zenodo.13365838 GHGConcentrations mon http://www.tbd.invalid gm CR CC BY 4.0 atmos 0.4.0 CMIP 000101-202212

A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. CR-CMIP-1-0-0 also provides a smoother transition from ice core based records to more recent records (i.e. flask and in-situ samples) and more sensible pre-industrial values for gases with non-zero pre-industrial concentrations. A DOI is now also included in each file. Please use it so we can track usage of these files. In terms of science, CR-CMIP-1-0-0 updates to the latest ice core and AGAGE data, as well as using better data sources for HFC23, CF4, C2F6 and C3F8 than CR-CMIP-0-4-0. UOEXETER-CMIP-1-3-0 t.aubry@exeter.ac.uk None aerosolProperties mon https://input4mips-controlled-vocabularies-cvs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dataset-overviews/stratospheric-volcanic-so2-emissions-aod/ gnz uoexeter CC BY 4.0 atmos 1.3.0 CMIP 175001-202312
849 Published CMIP6Plus ssa True published v2.0.0 includes the following key updates: i) new H2SO4 number density variable replacing aerosol number density; ii) correction to the 1920-1978 ice-core dataset, improving consistency with pyrheliometer measurements and CMIP6. As a result of this change, the mean historical SAOD has decreased a bit, but it is still higher than CMIP6. Hence v1.3.1 is deprecated. 866 Published CMIP6Plus vd False published v1.3.0 updates the handling of small eruptions in the pre-satellite era. Hence v1.2.0 is deprecated. UOEXETER-CMIP-1-2-0 t.aubry@exeter.ac.uk None aerosolProperties mon http://www.tbd.invalid gnz uoexeter CC BY 4.0 atmos 1.2.0 CMIP 175001-202312
867 Published CMIP6Plus vd False published v1.3.1 does minor plus updates and adds the aerosol number density requested by some modelling groups. Hence v1.3.0 is deprecated. UOEXETER-CMIP-1-3-0 t.aubry@exeter.ac.uk None aerosolProperties mon https://input4mips-controlled-vocabularies-cvs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dataset-overviews/stratospheric-volcanic-so2-emissions-aod/ gnz uoexeter CC BY 4.0 atmos 1.3.0 CMIP 175001-202312
868 Published CMIP6Plus vd True published v2.0.0 includes the following key updates: i) new H2SO4 number density variable replacing aerosol number density; ii) correction to the 1920-1978 ice-core dataset, improving consistency with pyrheliometer measurements and CMIP6. As a result of this change, the mean historical SAOD has decreased a bit, but it is still higher than CMIP6. Hence v1.3.1 is deprecated. As a result of this change, the mean historical SAOD has decreased a bit, but it is still higher than CMIP6. Hence v1.3.1 is deprecated. 877 Retracted CMIP6Plus multiple False retracted An issue was encountered with the proton ionization data in v4.2. It was hence retracted. The original comment from the data provider is here. SOLARIS-HEPPA-CMIP-4-2 bernd@iaa.es None solar day http://solarisheppa.geomar.de/cmip7 gn SOLARIS-HEPPA CC BY 4.0 atmos 4.2 CMIP 18500101-20231231
878 Retracted CMIP6Plus multiple False retracted v4.4 uses the final, absolute TSI scale (in consonance with NNL1) which should be used in CMIP7. Hence v4.3 is retracted. The change between v4.3 and v4.4 results in a 179 ppm increase of TSI and SSI compared to version 4.3. The preliminary TSI/SSI version in 4.3 had adapted the TSI scale from the CTIM instrument alone, the newer TSI scale is based on a TSIS-1 and CTIM composite (Coddington and Lean, 2024). This composite is also consistent with the TSI 'community consensus' composite (spot.colorado.edu/~koppg/TSI/TSI_Composite-SIST.txt). The original comment from the data provider is here. For further information, see SOLARIS-HEPPA release notes. SOLARIS-HEPPA-CMIP-4-3 bernd@iaa.es None solar day http://solarisheppa.geomar.de/cmip7 gn SOLARIS-HEPPA CC BY 4.0 atmos 4.3 CMIP 18500101-20231231
879 Retracted CMIP6Plus multiple False retracted v4.5 resolves issues with MEE short-term variability. Hence v4.4 is retracted. There are no changes to SSI/TSI (so, if you have used v4.4 for SSI/TSI, you do not need to restart). The original comment from the data provider is here. For further information, see SOLARIS-HEPPA release notes. SOLARIS-HEPPA-CMIP-4-4 bernd@iaa.es None solar day http://solarisheppa.geomar.de/cmip7 gn SOLARIS-HEPPA None atmos 4.4 CMIP 18500101-20231231

884 Retracted CMIP6Plus multiple False retracted v4.4 uses the final, absolute TSI scale (in consonance with NNL1) which should be used in CMIP7. Hence v4.3 is retracted. The change between v4.3 and v4.4 results in a 179 ppm increase of TSI and SSI compared to version 4.3. The preliminary TSI/SSI version in 4.3 had adapted the TSI scale from the CTIM instrument alone, the newer TSI scale is based on a TSIS-1 and CTIM composite (Coddington and Lean, 2024). This composite is also consistent with the TSI 'community consensus' composite (spot.colorado.edu/~koppg/TSI/TSI_Composite-SIST.txt). The original comment from the data provider is here.
